Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2012 05:26PM kltb04 wrote: Ack on the makeup!!! Yes little things like that don't seem to matter anymore. If my parents were not here we would manage but barely. Today my mom took my oldest to get some pants she needed for school and to get me a few things. Things that would just be harder for the hubby to do.
Posts.Title: The now official diagnosis IndigoMont11 Iz_and_Lys_Mum

Posts.Content: Mar 8, 2012 01:47PM kltb04 wrote: Hi Indigo - I got behind the last couple days so I missed the post about the MRI.  Yay that that it is only the one side.  Boooooooo that it is larger than they thought.  Because mine was done on a Friday and not read until Monday morning,  I don't think I ever actually discussed my MRI with my BS except for the 10 minutes before my SNB when she told me they didn't find any other areas of concern.  Reminds me that I need to get that lab report to add to my "book of knowledge".  My MRI was smooth too - if I had had a xanax, I could have totally fallen asleep in there.  I actually DID fall asleep after my injection for my PET scan yesterday (I had to wait 70 minutes for it to "kick in" before the scan).  When I woke up, it was one of those "omg, where am I" moments. And I am with you on the BMX...even if the chemo shrinks mine down, I am going with that. I will be be keeping up with you.  Let us know how your appt goes next week.
Posts.Title: The now official diagnosis IndigoMont11 Iz_and_Lys_Mum

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 05:36PM kltb04 wrote: Oh sweetie, I am so sorry, (((HUGS)))...and quite frankly, I want to kick him in the ass.  There is a difference between being him sad for you and the situation and being selfish and making a judgement that is causing you to feel bad.  Thinking of you....
Posts.Title: The now official diagnosis IndigoMont11 Iz_and_Lys_Mum

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 09:01AM kltb04 wrote: Hi Indigo - glad things are going okay...I hadn't thought of needing a recliner until everyone keeps talking about them so I guess that may be in our future.  Our furniture has HAD it.  It isn't that old (about 6 1/2 years since we bought it) but two kids and three cats have taken their toll. (soon to be two cats, one is on her way out the door, I will post about that on "my" thread)   I think if we get one though I will squeeze it in our bedroom so I can be out of the way. After having this drain for only three days I can see I will need some of those camisoles as well before surgery but I have months to go before that.  Where are you getting them? Tammy, lol, that is what I think off the house dusters/dresses but I suppose those would be most accomodating after surgery!
Posts.Title: The now official diagnosis IndigoMont11 Iz_and_Lys_Mum

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 11:41AM kltb04 wrote: Ours is microfiber which practically is a fur magnet.  Plus the one cat is a scratcher and she has messed up the corners.  And the structure of it just hasn't held up well...it sinks down in the corners so we are probably due for furniture anyway.   My poor DH has been relegated to the younger dd's rooms because the girls sleep in the older ones room...I will consider letting him come back in lol now that the animals and kids are out.  But he snores so maybe not.  I will just have a king size bed AND a recliner to myself. :) I will check the website out.  I am sure there is something in Little Rock that sells stuff that I could check out on the one million appointments I have down there. I don't own any button down shirts either!  Nothing...They would have come in handy during this sideline trip I have had with the surgeries/drain/port, etc...I am very self conscious too.  by no means a fashionista but I have a very particular way I want to look or I don't feel good about myself...when I am out that is.  At home I am a total slob! Funny you should say that.  Exactly one month since my dx/phone call from the radiologist.  I knew already though since I had grilled him the day before (after my biopsy) and had him admit it was likely IDC. But that confirmation call was still rough.
Posts.Title: The now official diagnosis IndigoMont11 Iz_and_Lys_Mum

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2012 07:30PM kltb04 wrote: Hi Indigo...just popping over to see your situation since you were the first to post on mine!  Sounds like you are doing much better than I was when I first got my diagnosis.  LOL on the nook - I got a Kindle for Christmas but hadn't really done much with it until all this came about...then I loaded that sucker up with new books! I agree on the email (or FB as someone said) being a good way to inform people.  It gives them time to digest the information and decide how they are going to respond.  When you tell people on the phone, or face to face, they are often so shocked, they just don't know what to say.  The most hurtful thing to me so far have been people who don't respond at all. Glad for you too that yours appears to be slow growing...mine is aggressive and just seems to be moving at warp speed from what I can figure. :( Have a great weekend and I will be thinking of you...
Posts.Title: The now official diagnosis IndigoMont11 Iz_and_Lys_Mum

Posts.Content: May 11, 2012 03:16PM kltb04 wrote: I haven't had my big surgery yet (doing neoadjuvant chemo) but I did have a SNB after diagnosis in February and a subsequent re-excision surgery to clean out the area after a seroma and everything you are feeling is normal!  Mine is much better now (2 1/2 months later) but I still have lack of sensation under the arm and I can't do some things I am used to, like sleeping on my stomach with my arm under my pillow. It is a gradual return to "normal" and definitely a "new normal" feeling but it did get better gradually. As far as the incision, I kept an antibacterial ointment on it when I thought of it, lol, just basically kept it clean and dry.
Posts.Title: SNB ...underarm movement/pain etc purple32 purple32

Posts.Content: Mar 10, 2012 09:59AM kltb04 wrote: Lostinmo. I feel the same way about the drs and tests. I can't believe that I have gone from someone whose only visits to the dr were for the occasional sinus infections (besides having my kids) to someone that has had an MRI, CT, PET, and MUGA scans, 2 surgeries, and more blood drawn and ivs than I can count in just 3 1/2 weeks. I used to have such a dread of hospitals and drs offices. Now I am trying to look at them as what will help me. When I was having my PET I just lay there and thought "thank you God for this technology and access to it.".

Posts.Title: The now official diagnosis IndigoMont11 Iz_and_Lys_Mum

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2012 10:00PM kltb04 wrote: Hi Amy - sorry for your news but happy you found this site.  I was dx in Feb with triple positive cancer at the age of 38. My BS/MO both recommended neoadjuvant chemo and it worked - I had about a 50% reduction in size after 4 cycles of A/C (from 3 cm to about 1.5) and I am pretty sure I had more shrinkage after my last 4 cycles (Taxotere).  However, since I am choosing a bilateral masectomy (strictly my choice, lumpectomy was an option), I haven't had any more tests to determine the size.  I am scheduled for surgery on Oct 1st. I don't remember any questions I asked my MO at first - I think I was too overwhelmed!  Good luck in your journey...
Posts.Title: 34 and just got diagnosed Aug 22, 2012 and have many concerns... Amy4978 annabug12

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2012 12:46AM kltb04 wrote: Another piece of advice I would give you is that when you start chemo, find a group on here that is starting at the same time - even if they aren't doing the exact regimen as you, it helps to have those to go through it with!  I made some great friends on the March 2012 chemo board!
Posts.Title: 34 and just got diagnosed Aug 22, 2012 and have many concerns... Amy4978 annabug12

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2012 02:42AM kltb04 wrote: Mine are a little older 9 and 12.  I think the younger the kids are, the harder it is, but you are right, you have lots to live for!  Plus - and you are gonna get sick of hearing this but its true - it seems like you have a great attitude and that really helps as far as keeping your spirits up, etc... Best of luck - keep us posted!
Posts.Title: 34 and just got diagnosed Aug 22, 2012 and have many concerns... Amy4978 annabug12

Posts.Content: Aug 26, 2012 07:59PM kltb04 wrote: It is strictly a personal choice Amy - to my knowledge, the survival benefits of BMX or lumpectomy plus rads is the same.  But there is an increased chance of recurrance (local) with lump plus rads.  Of course, there are no guarantees with BMX either but that is part of my reason.  I hope to have a lot of years left and don't want to be dealing with the stress of mammos and such for those years.  After my diagnostic mammo, I had an MRI which showed no issues in my other breast - but I just don't want to deal with it later if something happens. I am having immediate reconstruction if all goes as planned.  Immediate Tissue Expanders (TEs) and then exchange surgery to implants about 6 months later.  Advantages and disadvantages to this as well - major disadvantage is that they do have to be replaced after a point - I will cross that bridge when I come to it.
Posts.Title: 34 and just got diagnosed Aug 22, 2012 and have many concerns... Amy4978 annabug12

Posts.Content: Aug 27, 2012 01:34AM kltb04 wrote: I cut mine and then buzzed it myself once it started falling out - I have a wig but with the heat this summer, I don't ever wear it.  Just scarves and hats.  I had my last chemo on Aug 13th and my hair had already started coming back before I was even done - it all depends on what kind of chemo you have, how your body reacts, etc...I hope I don't lose it again (can happen but I hope not!) Smoothies will be ok as long as you don't have restrictions with your white counts (sometimes some oncs will recommend you peel or cook all fruits/veggies) - I only had a really low count once.  And hate veggies so it wasn't an issue. LOL/ Anyway, feel free to PM me anytime if you have questions.  I don't come on here as often anymore as I did in the beginning but still check BCO everyday.  I just happened to catch your age and the title of your thread when I was on so I posted! :)
Posts.Title: 34 and just got diagnosed Aug 22, 2012 and have many concerns... Amy4978 annabug12

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2012 11:58AM kltb04 wrote: If your radiologist will talk to you over the phone, call him and see if he can give you anymore info.  I think who does what depends on what kind of facility you go to.  I went to a Women's Health Imaging Center so they all did the "breast stuff" - there were about 8 radiologists on staff though so you just kind of took what you got that day! It may well be that only certain radiologists do or read the biopsies so you just need a longer appt time.  That said, if you can talk to someone to ease your mind, do so.  Regardless (and easier said than done) try your damndest to put it out of your mind this weekend.  If it is nothing, you will have ruined your vacation, if it is something, you will have ruined your vacation.  You will be able to deal with it full force after you get back, either way.  (((HUGS))) and I will keep you in my thoughts and prayers. "Don't spend a lot of time imagining worst case scenario.  It rarely goes down as you imagine it will, and if by some fluke it does, you will have lived it twice."  Michael J. Fox
Posts.Title: Biopsies Worries nandksmom Lily55

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2012 09:06AM kltb04 wrote: Still thinking about you and praying for good results and peace of mine for you as you continue your vacation.
Posts.Title: Biopsies Worries nandksmom Lily55

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2012 02:55PM kltb04 wrote: It requires surgery - and there are risks of complications (such as puncturing a lung, etc...) so additional risks there.
Posts.Title: Port vs. picc autism_mom ridergirl

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2012 02:40PM kltb04 wrote: Good question!  I have a port but I wasn't given an option.  My MO nurse said "oh, you might want to think abouta port before you start chemo" I suppose a port is more invasive but imo, it is easier to deal with rather than something being in your arm.  Some people can't stand the thought of the port, something beneath their skin.  Mine doesn't bother me.  I love the convenience of it. (can't have sticks on my right side due to having a SNB and my veins are already little and crawly so I was running out of good ones on my left).
Posts.Title: Port vs. picc autism_mom ridergirl

Posts.Content: Jul 21, 2012 03:15PM kltb04 wrote: I have no regrets about my port either.  It gets kind of janky sometimes (takes a while to get going) but it eventually works.  I don't *think* mine is a power port but I get draws out of it every week (get my labs done before each TX and each week thereafter) and my chemo in it.  I just know I can't use it for scans - PET, etc...
Posts.Title: Port vs. picc autism_mom ridergirl

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 07:12AM kltb04 wrote: I just posted on two young ladies' threads here that are in their 20s.  I am 38 and I got the whole "you're too young" speech from my ob/gyn APN but thankfully she was proactive enough and I was paranoid enough that I went in for a diagnostic mammo when she found a "ridge" in my breast.  I have to think that the things listed that are in our environment, food, and other things have to be contributing to this, well, epidemic, for lack of a better word!  Personally, I have an awful diet as far as just too much processed food and that is one thing I can improve on (once I am past chemo, I am just eating to survive at this point.)  Interesting to see what others have to say on this topic.
Posts.Title: Don't know where to put this topic barbiecorn kltb04

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2012 10:29AM kltb04 wrote: Wow at all the stories! My BS is super enthusiastic and optimistic - to a fault.  I LOVE her but she told my parents and DH (after my SNB when they were discussing chemo) that it really wasn't that big of deal, people just go on about their lives and work, etc...(not sure of her exact words).  Although I realize some do, I knew otherwise from reading on here, that many people DO NOT and I felt like I had the expectation  from them that I should be going through chemo SE free!  I was horribly nauseous and had awful pain from the Nuelasta, no appetite, etc... Anyway all of that to say that I really wish she had not led them to believe that this was a walk in the park.  My MO is very quiet and conservative in her words.  I think I have approached her more with a "don't ask don't tell" type policy.  I haven't asked her for stats or anything, we just discuss my treatment.  On the plus side she is very good at wanting to help manage SE and will prescribe anything under the sun if she thinks she can help.
Posts.Title: What does/did your MO/RO/BS/PS say that made you want to scream? Momof2inME Wordwrangler

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2012 06:17AM kltb04 wrote:  Rachel - your age really wouldn't have a darn thing to do with whether you carry a gene I would think???  If you have a gene, you have a gane and even if you choose not to do anything else preventatively, your children (if you have them) have a right to know! My understanding is that BMX vs lumpectomy/rads don't necessarily increase the chance of survival, but there is slightly more of a chance of recurrance (someone correct me if I am wrong).  Regardless, it is your decision...I am having neoadjuvant chemo on a 3 cm tumor and lumpectomy will likely be an option but it is my personal decision to have a BMX when chemo is done.
Posts.Title: What does/did your MO/RO/BS/PS say that made you want to scream? Momof2inME Wordwrangler

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 09:18AM kltb04 wrote: Lana - going to PM you...I feel like I can't even get past the fear of "occurance" much less recurrance...I don't know what it is going to take to convince me that every ache and pain isn't mets.  I dread going to the MO before each TX because I feel like I need to tell her any little tiny thing I am worried about and that rather than reassuring me, she is going to order another scan that might find something.  And as you know, I am not even 1/2 way through chemo yet - (((sigh)))...maybe I need to go read some of those positive quotes I am always posting.  Hope it's ok I posted here, I am IIB rather than III but who knows since I only had the SNB if I might've had more +nodes.
Posts.Title: Does the looming dread of recurrence ever go away? lanagraves fondak

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 10:13AM kltb04 wrote: I think so too (about the staging) - I don't think my MO puts a lot of empasis on staging in general - I wouldn't even know mine if I hadn't seen it on my chart.  She isn't big into stats, numbers of any kind from what I gather.
Posts.Title: Does the looming dread of recurrence ever go away? lanagraves fondak

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 05:05PM kltb04 wrote: "Don't spend a lot of time fixating on the worst case scenario.  It rarely goes down as you imagine it will, and if by some fluke it does, you will have lived it twice."   Micheal J. Fox All that said, I still do it (imagining worst case scenario).  But I am really good at remembering quotes ;)
Posts.Title: Does the looming dread of recurrence ever go away? lanagraves fondak

Posts.Content: Mar 29, 2012 02:02PM kltb04 wrote: In regard to "self interpretation" I so wanted to see my PET results before I went to my MO on a Monday that I had DH call and ask the nurse who works the weekend/desk shift that Saturday and ask to hear them over the phone. They couldn't find them - thank God for that.  Because when I did see them I saw "physiological uptake in the ovary" and I would have SHUT DOWN had I heard that over the phone.  Even the nurse was like "oh it's probably nothing" but I had to hear the MO say "this is fine, you still have ovaries, and they were working at the time, it is normal"  and ask her "so you are saying this is not a concern" and have her repeat to me "this is not an area of concern" for me to believe her.
Posts.Title: had to share momand2kids paradiju

Posts.Content: Mar 28, 2012 03:52PM kltb04 wrote: OMG that just literally made me LOL and share that story with those in the room with me!  Totally something I would do.
Posts.Title: had to share momand2kids paradiju

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2012 06:28PM kltb04 wrote: Judy - I just saw this - that is too funny!  But it wasn't supposed to be that way.  My mom knew an exchange student in HS from Germany named Kari and always liked the name.  My dad actually misspelled it on the paperwork at the hospital and added the -r- so they kept it that way!  I have yet to meet anyone in person with it spelled the same way.  I used to HATE it because people would spell it Karie, Kari, Kerry, you name it.  But after 38 years, I have learned to accept it!  To add insult to injury, my middle name Lynne - has an e - which isn't as uncommon but still! And FWIW (though not uncommon), my MIL is named Judy! :)
Posts.Title: had to share momand2kids paradiju

Posts.Content: Apr 6, 2012 09:29AM kltb04 wrote: Another neo chemo chick here - mine is just my drs protocol rather than tumor size or anything (3 cm) - A/Cx4 then I guess TaxolX4 (I am not sure, just dealing with my second round of A/C next week).  So I am looking at chemo through about mid September and then a break and then surgery. Lumpectomy has been presented as an option but my personal decision is BMX with reconstruction and I doubt I will change my mind.  I am 38. Taking it a day at a time - been on these boards since right after I was dx in Feb and it has been a lifesaver.
Posts.Title: Anyone else doing TAC neoadjuvant chemotherapy lisa224 GeorgiaRai

Posts.Content: May 19, 2012 10:47PM kltb04 wrote: Pamela -  hi there, I am another "neo chemo" chick here :)  My tumor was "only" 3 cm but the BS/MO I see prefer to use the chemo first if at all possible not only to shrink it but also to see what it responds best too.  I was dx at the end of February and had a sentinel node biopsy first...then chemo started in mid March.  I am having A/C x 4 and then Taxotere x 4 (Herceptin also will be added at that time due to me being Her2+ something you don't have to deal with). So 8 rounds around 3 weeks apart works out to about 6 months, then a break I presume, then surgery.  We haven't even discussed rads yet.  I have a port too - it will be your best friend, trust me, especially if you have crappy veins like I do. Hair - Ah wigs - this hair thing has been the bane of my existance - I shaved mine all off as soon as it started coming out.  I am in Arkansas so humidity and heat here too is going to make my wig so uncomfortable.  I bought a good (read $$) monofilament wig that everyone says looks so natural and I cannot stand it most of the time.  I can't do the scarf thing by itself but I can do a scarf, tied at the base of my neck with a cap or hat on top.  I just need to get some cotton scarves.  The ones I have are silky/polyester.  My hats I have so far are just inexpensive cute/blingy things I have picked up at the Dollar General or Walmart.  I have also tried ordering halos (wigs that are topless and for wearing under hats) but sent two back already because of comfort/fit.    Good luck as you get started - I advise everyone just starting out to find a corresponding "Chemo" board to post on as well...even if they aren't getting exactly the same treatment as you, it helps having people at similar stages going through it at the same time.   One last thing - Craftylass - how are they measuring your tumor, if you don't mind me asking?  My MO gives me a quick "feel up" (lol) before each TX but she hasn't once mentioning shrinkage or evaluating it??? I go on Monday for A/C #4.  I poke around myself a bit but it was kind of hard to find in the first place (mine was more of a shallow/long "ridge" rather than a hard round lump).  Just wondering.
Posts.Title: Question about chemo before surgery pamelahope kltb04

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 07:39PM - edited Apr 1, 2012 07:40PM by kltb04 I have A/C every 3 weeks but I am on the March chemo boards with those doing T/C. Side effects vary of course but most of us just have a rough first week and then weeks 2 and 3 are better. Therr are some that have very few SE For me personally days 3-5 were worst. 6-7 better. And by the first part of last week I felt about normal again except for being tired and my white blood count being low. I think that our of our March ladies had started a March/April T/C board you might search for. Good luck on your first TX
Posts.Title: Differences in Side Effects PamCA claireinaz

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 11:54PM kltb04 wrote: Pam I did the Claritin day before and 5 days after but during the pain I took Percocet. My MO gave me an rX because I needed more from my biopsy site being redone but also just to have a pain killer on hand. She said she didn't want me going home 60 mikes away and not bring prepared. FYI my pain felt like muscles and even skin rather than bone pain. Who knows if it was the shot or the chemo. The bad night I took Percocet every 3-4 hrs and I had taken phenagran for nausea. For daytime nausea though I took Zofran.
Posts.Title: Differences in Side Effects PamCA claireinaz

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2012 02:26AM kltb04 wrote: When is the appt, do you know yet?  If not could you call back the original dr or radiologist and ask some questions?  I feel for you hon, I really do.  It is so scary.  Try not to google yourself to death before you know what you are dealing with, if anything.  (((HUGS)))
Posts.Title: What to expect? ScaredSingleMom kltb04

Posts.Content: May 16, 2012 02:36PM kltb04 wrote: I am having some issues as well that my MO doesn't have an easy answer for - fullness and slight discomfort in the rib cage on the opposite side of my cancer.  I am not quite halfway through neoadjuvant chemo (4 x A/C and 4 X TH after) and have only had a SNB on the right side.  This issue is on the left side under my "healthy" breast and in the rib area.  No real shortness of breath, just a feeling of discomfort.  I had actually noticed the discomfort mildly before I even was dx w/BC.   Upon diagnosis, I had a head CT, head to toe PET/CT (all clear)...when I brought up these symptoms to MO last month, she ordered rib xrays - nothing showed up.  Called BS office and the nurse just said perhaps I was "overcompensating" on the non cancer side.  (((sigh))) have googled the heck out of it and find lots of people (cancer or no) have issues in this area and sometimes never get resolution. Guess I will bring it up yet again at 4th A/C appt Monday.
Posts.Title: Who got Pleurisy and other "rare" SE from chemo? SleeplessIn kltb04

Posts.Content: Jul 12, 2012 08:33AM kltb04 wrote: Your title of your post sounds similar to mine when I was first diagnosed...except I think mine said "fearing the worst" :)  I will share a quote that someone shared with me on that first thread.  "Don't spend a lot of time imagining worst case scenario.  It rarely goes down as you imagine it will and if by some fluke it does, you will have lived it twice."  Michael J. Fox I think I was more nervous about my pre chemo scans than I was for chemo itself!  (I had a sentinel node biopsy and am having chemo first, then surgery this fall).   My scans came back clean but I still worry, I think we all do.   About your pain, I have a consistent issue that sounds really similar to yours - it is my left side rather than my right (my cancer is on the right) and it is a "tight" weird sensation around my ribs.    Like I said, my PET was clean, I had rib xrays after I mentioned it to my MO and we have just decided it is either stress or just some kind of other issue that is non cancer related.  So glad your daughter is doing well and I have no doubt you will as well.  Keep us posted and feel free to PM any one of us if we can help you with any questions.  Hang in there.
Posts.Title: waiting on staging tests and scared steviesmom kltb04

Posts.Content: Jul 18, 2012 09:14AM kltb04 wrote: steviesmom - yikes, glad no one was hurt.  Glad you got a second opinion.  Keep us posted on your progress.  One thing that helps immensely during chemo is to join (or start) a thread when you start chemo.  Even if you aren't on the exact same chemo - it really helps to be going through it with others. Christine - thanks for the reassurance on the "rib thing" - I go for spells where I don't worry about it at all and then I will obsess about it for awhile!  It is definitely worse when I am sedentary for a long period of time and/or don't wear a bra, lol (I haven't had surgery yet, still in chemo).
Posts.Title: waiting on staging tests and scared steviesmom kltb04

Posts.Content: Mar 11, 2012 04:18AM kltb04 wrote: I researched long and hard from diagnosis until I met with the drs. Since then I have been trying to keep informed but not drive myself nuts. Fwiw my surgeon indicates that unless it is just a tee tiny or contained area she and the oncologist she works with recommend the neoadjuvant (before surgery) chemo which is what I will have starting Monday. She said that even before my sentinel node biopsy. It has the benefit of getting the chemo in your system straightaway and not waiting to heal after surgery plus they can see what your particular cancer will respond to. I got my port yesterday. I can only have blood draws and Iv in my left arm now and all my veins are shot so I am happy for it.
Posts.Title: I tried, but I don't get it.. lostinmo lago

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 06:07PM kltb04 wrote: Most people on my chemo board take Claritin for the pain.  I did as well.  I don't know how much it helped or how much worse the pain might have been if I hadn't taken it but I still had pain a couple days later that I took Percocet for...as far as the other reactions go, yikes!  I know that some people only take half the regular dosage of subsequent Nuelasta injections if they have problems with it.
Posts.Title: Anyone else have a bad reaction to neulasta? SAR843 BetsyBuzz

Posts.Content: May 19, 2012 11:44PM kltb04 wrote: Craftylass - I so wish they would do that for me!  It would make me feel better.  I am having some other issues with my ribs (upon poking and prodding, I found an area that I am praying is a cyst or lipoma) and I know that if my A/C is working, there is no way that would have just popped up/grown in the time since my last scans (I was scanned at diagnosis)...I will ask my MO on Monday when/how we are going to assess if things are shrinking. LOL on your bald head encounters with the receptionist!  And glad to hear that someone else is growing hair between TX too.  Like I said, I shaved mine clean to the scalp when it started going but I am having some regrowth on my head - and also growth on my legs - no fair!   Sorry to have hijacked your thread Pamela!
Posts.Title: Question about chemo before surgery pamelahope kltb04

Posts.Content: May 31, 2012 11:26PM kltb04 wrote: The waiting is the absolute worst part, I promise.  It will get better.  So they are basically doing an excisional biopsy and removing the mass, correct?  Let us know when you get it scheduled and know more.
Posts.Title: What to expect? ScaredSingleMom kltb04

Posts.Content: Apr 5, 2012 05:56PM kltb04 wrote: I tried just the different single serve flavors you add to bottled waters and found some of them were tolerable if they had a really strong flavor.  I couldn't stand my usual favorite drink (diet coke). And couldn't even think about coffee. About to start the fun again Monday for second round of A/C so I need to stock up on some things this weekend!
Posts.Title: What to drink to quench thirst? JoanQuilts Hortense

Posts.Content: Apr 15, 2012 10:48AM kltb04 wrote: Just saw your post - you will surely have time to meet with your BS and go over options?  I don't have any experience with the surgeries yet as I am doing neoadjuvant chemo (chemo first) but I am planning on BMX after chemo regardless of results. Another voice of assurance on nodes - I had a sentinel node biopsy and 1 of 4 nodes was positive but my MO and BS both just said that their treatment would be the same regardless.  And they also don't talk stats.  So many people say "oh at least it wasn't in my lymph nodes" but ya know what - that is your lymph nodes doing their job!   Keep us posted and try not to worry too much...when/if you find out about your surgery, you can probably go to one of the April surgery boards and get info from people going through it now as well.  (((HUGS)))
Posts.Title: Diagnosis-IDC. MRI shows enlarged lymph node.HELP luvBngGma christina0001

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 05:17AM kltb04 wrote: You know what I have also found about these boards is that once you get on them and start talking to people, you start even talking about other things and you forget about the BC for a little while...while at the same time you know they know how you feel.  I am ok when I have the drs appts to go to because I feel like I am DOING something.  But I feel sad several times a day, usually I cry alone.  It has always been "my" job to get the kids up and ready for school and since I have been down (I have had some complications), it kills me to be in my room waking up and hearing my husband getting them up for school.  I cry when I think of what I should be doing on my kids spring break and what the reality is.  I cry when my youngest asks if she can hug me and I can't because of my incision/drains and because I am terrified of any infection before I start chemo.  I cry after my oldest asks for the hundredth time when we are doing her birthday party and I want to snap "let me get through a week of chemo and I will get back to you!"   One thing I would advise - and I don't take this advice, I just dispense it - try to keep living.  I know you are in a state of waiting/limbo but try to keep going as much as you can without just shutting down.  I am an "if,then" type person.  "If I find out the biopsy is ok, then I will do so and so" or "The biopsy came back; I have cancer but if I find out it hasn't spread, then I will be able to look forward to this or that"  And I can't live that way anymore.  It has become much more about living in the now.  I am still in limbo because I haven't started chemo yet and I had to have a second surgery on my biopsy site so I am giving myself a pass on doing anything this weekend (especially with a drain and infection) but once chemo starts I am going to make more of an effort to keep going, be more active, etc...as much as my side effects will allow. Hang in there..there are going to be a bunch more tests and waiting but you can do it.  And here is some good advice about worst case scenarios that I got from someone on another thread.  "Don't spend a lot of time imagining the worse case scenario.  It rarely goes down as you imagine it will, and if by some fluke it does, you will have lived it twice."  Micheal J. Fox.
Posts.Title: worried about everything anndh christina0001

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 12:48PM kltb04 wrote: Mine is better - still very uncomfortable but not the intense stabbing/pinching pain I had for the first days but there is a drain so that is adding to it. The redness and swelling is gone now.  I just think that after all is said and done, I am still going to have issues with the nerves, pain, lack of sensation and I guess I will have to get used to it.
Posts.Title: Sentinel Node Biopsy kltb04 Gina9195

Posts.Content: Mar 17, 2012 04:58PM kltb04 wrote: THanks Layla - it looks soooo much better than it did and the drainage looks lighter and less by the day so fingers crossed we got the infection cleared up and the drain will come out Monday.  We are still being vigilant about the incisions/drain site and keeping it clean/dry/covered.  I freaked out earlier because I spilled some water down my top from a water bottle and was worried I had gotten the bandage wet (it hadn't). How I managed to do that sitting still drinking from a water bottle I do not know. On the plus side I haven't had any complications or issues from the port besides the initial soreness.   I think you only have to have it flushed if you haven't used it for a certain period of time.  But I'm not sure.
Posts.Title: Sentinel Node Biopsy kltb04 Gina9195

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 06:34AM kltb04 wrote: Hi there...I had a bit of disturbing news at my MO visit today.  I am a little over halfway through neoadjuvant chemo (A/C x 4) (Taxotere x 4).  Was diagnosed, had PET/CT combo at diagnosis which was clear.  I started having some rib discomfort (not pain) and had a clear xray since chemo was started.  Anyway, after my MO examined me and had left the room and my nurse was going over upcoming appts she just said "I am going to make a note to myslelf that your calcium level is a little high".  And I just immediately thought - and SAID - oh no, that could mean bone mets.  Then she started trying to reassure me, telling me it wasn't that high, it could be diet related, etc...but it was too late.  The worry train has left the station.  I think she said it was 10.6 and high level of normal is 10.2.  So here I sit.  I don't take any calcium supplements or anything and I can't imagine anything in my horrible diet could be to blame.  I know there is nothing to do but wait and see but was hoping to hear of others that might have had this issue....
Posts.Title: If you are not Stage IV but have questions, you may post here chrissyb Olma61

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2012 06:57AM kltb04 wrote: Ok, well, I am not going to delete my post because I hate it when that happens but I just called back to the drs office - I thought I would ask what my levels were before so I could compare them/see how much they had risen.  Got a different nurse and I guess they had been talking about me :) because she didn't even pull my chart she just said "oh honey, she repeated the test and they were within normal levels."  9.something? So I am relieved but at the same time, how could they repeat the test with no more blood?  Oh well, I am not going to worry about it right now.  Thanks for listening.

Posts.Content: Apr 3, 2012 09:52AM kltb04 wrote: I had dimpling too - when I raised my arms above my head and pressed my palms together - it was very slight but it was there at the spot where my APN found a "ridge".  I had diagnostic mammogram, then us, then stereotactic biopsy.  MRI was after dx and ordered by my BS to rule out any other areas of concern.
Posts.Title: Dimpling? Ann216 Ann216

Posts.Content: kltb04 wrote: Hi all. I had a sentinel node biopsy on 2/27 so not quite two weeks ago. I will be doing neo adjuvant chemo before probable BMX so there wasn't a lumpectomy. BS took 4 nodes. I was told to expect some pain and soreness and to watch for signs of infection. Had a follow up on the 5th with the nurse to remove steri strips and all looked fine. It just feels worse than ever. Not the incision site itself but under my arm and my actual armpit. It hurts as much as it did the day after. I thought it had gotten better for a while but it seems worse now. To add to this, I had my put in yesterday so now I am useless. in pain on right side from SNB and left from the port. BS looked at it yesterday and said the site looked fine. I am just wondering if anyone else has had problems from "just" a SNB? Like I said no infection, no swelling just PAIN and it feels like I am about to tear my arm apart when I move it. Dx 2/17/2012, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Surgery 2/27/2012 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Chemotherapy 3/19/2012 AC Targeted Therapy 6/11/2012 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Chemotherapy 6/11/2012 Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 10/1/2012 Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left; Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Radiation Therapy 11/13/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 11/18/2012 Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: Sentinel Node Biopsy kltb04 Gina9195

Posts.Content: Mar 13, 2012 10:55AM kltb04 wrote: Just an update if anyone runs across this thread later.  I have had a post surgical complication that has been horrendous and delayed chemo.  Usually, if you are going to have problems it is within 24-72 hrs of your sentinel node biopsy.  Although I had significant pain and motion problems after the surgery, they were better in about a week.  It was not until 13 days after that I developed a problem and we still don't know the cause.  I had some kind of infection starting about day 11 that was just a virus or flu like illness; I then had my port placement, my fever spiked to 103, went down and 2 days later I had swelling, a seroma, redness, soreness.  It was aspirated yesterday (2 days after surgery) and continues to drain.  I was supposed to start chemo and cannot.  I go back to the BS today to re-evaluate. Just a cautionary tale that the SNB - even alone without BMX or lumpectomy - can be a major ordeal.
Posts.Title: Sentinel Node Biopsy kltb04 Gina9195

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 11:58PM kltb04 wrote: Oh I forgot about the mouth sores. I got some under my tongue about day 6. Some drs rX a mouthwash with lidocaine Benadryl and an antifungal. I just used the Biotene mouthwash you can buy and kind of dealt with it. A week later and it's better. I have canker sores and ulcers quite a bit so guess I am used to mouth issues.

Well, my BS had to go back in to the original site, clean it out, and put in a drain - yuck. I have to leave it in until Monday and hopefully they will be able to pull it out and I can start chemo...

Posts.Content: Apr 1, 2012 07:45PM kltb04 wrote: Ok I wasn't real specific lol. Day one I had diarrhea but I ate a really large meal after chemo. Lol. Day two I had the Nuelasta shot and I was ok that afternoon. I started feeling kind of bad that night and then felt really bad (nausea, fatigue but not sleeping, and pain) day 3 into day 4. Then after that it was just periodic nausea when I got up and around etc. My advice is to stay ahead of your nausea and take meds whether you think you need them or not.
Posts.Title: Differences in Side Effects PamCA claireinaz

Posts.Content: May 30, 2012 11:01PM kltb04 wrote: Hang in there...there is really no way to know what is going to happen but just trust that you are doing exactly what you should be doing to find out what is going on.  If it's nothing, you will have worried yourself for no reason and if it's something, you will be started in the right direction to have things taken care of.  I'm 38 with young kids and you will find a lot of "younger" folks here.  Oh and don't let it freak you out either that a lot of us that will give you advice are in the "it's something" camp since that is why we post here, lol...(((hugs))) keep us posted.  Even if they see something on the u/s that they need to biopsy, the majority turn out benign, like mssunshine said.
Posts.Title: What to expect? ScaredSingleMom kltb04

Posts.Content: Jun 1, 2012 02:47AM kltb04 wrote: bev - ya know that is a good question - in a quick google search I did I found that they are really the same except a excisional biopsy is considered diagnostic and a lumpectomy is considered treatment.  I just know sometimes a excisional biopsy is done if they don't think they can get a good sample.  I had a core biopsy where they sucked up the tissue samples through a large hollow needle...maybe if the mass is a different/firmer consistancy it is better to excise?
Posts.Title: What to expect? ScaredSingleMom kltb04

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2012 05:38AM kltb04 wrote: (((hugs))) I am right there with you.  I have gone from a "let's do this and kick cancer's a$$" attitude to just being sad.   Just sad that things are never going to be the same and that my family is having to go through all this.  I have had a delay in treatment/chemo becuase of a complication with my SNB and I am so discouraged. Just hang in there.  I find I feel differently from day to day.  If you need help coping and/or with anxiety, go for it.  I have a xanax rX but I am not taking it right now since I am on some pain meds. Good luck to you and keep us posted.
Posts.Title: worried about everything anndh christina0001

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2012 12:29PM kltb04 wrote: Lana - I would tell you from seeing my report to not try and read it yourself or interpret what the radiologist says. Mine showed things that were "physiological in nature" that I would have FREAKED about had I read it myself or not been able to talk to someone about it.  It turned out one thing was my gallbladder had "moderative activity" which caused me to be referred for an u/s (which showed nothing).  The other was "activity" in my ovary.  If the nurse had read that to me over the phone, I would have totally lost it.  The report clearly says that this was "physiological" for someone my age which means I was likely ovulating, etc...I had to be reassured by my BS, my MO, AND the radiologist (at different/times/appts this week) to feel better about things. Anyway, the imaging center told me last Wednesday that my doctors office would call me 2 days later on Friday with the results but they didn't and then I got sick so I forgot to call.  Glad I did.  As it was, I had to wait out the weekend but I was in the MO office to see the report.   Thoughts and prayers as you wait.
Posts.Title: worried about everything anndh christina0001

Posts.Content: Feb 20, 2013 07:53AM kltb04 wrote: I had a BMX WITH Te's because I was under the impression that I did not need rads (from my BS, PS mostly).  I was in a gray area because I had one positive node found during SNB.  After a LOT of research and two RO opinions, I decided to do rads....it is worth the extra insurance for me.  They take a lot of precautions to protect your heart/lungs.  Good luck with your decision.
Posts.Title: Should I get radiation ? I had BMX. new2bc NatsFan

Posts.Content: Aug 17, 2012 11:24PM kltb04 wrote: I have one and can't imagine doing chemo without - not just for chemo but for blood draws, etc...I only have one good arm due to not using my SNB side and even though I have rarely had so much as blood drawn before dx (and I am only 39), the veins in my good arm weren't that great.  With Herceptin for a year, it was something I didn't think twice about.  And I don't care if it shows - it isn't that noticeable - just a small bump under my skin - and that's the least of my worries!
Posts.Title: Port or no port??? Camillia lago

Posts.Content: kltb04 wrote: Hi all...I have been on the boards for a few weeks but new to this forum.  I had an ongoing thread called Just Diagnosed/Fearing the worst with a few people I talked to but I thought I would post a new thread since I am no longer either of those things!  I also post frequently and with an excess of words, on March 2012 Chemo.  I am a married mother of 2 girls (8 and 11), a certified teacher who hasn't taught in years, was working PT in retail until my dx and now at home full time.  My parents are actually living in an RV in our yard and they have been a great help. My story in a nutshell: My APN discovered a "ridge" in my right breast on my annual visit on 2/5.  I am 38, never had a mammo, so a whirlwind ensued...diagnostic mammo, biopsy, meeting with BS and MO, SNB, staging PET scan, CT/Muga, port placement, complications/infection from an infection (culture grew in my blood, no idea of source), re-excision of SNB site, drain inserted.  Yesterday, I got the drain out and started chemo. Which brings me to the other part of my topic.  My BS/MO suggested the neoadjuvant chemo before surgery although my tumor is not particularly large (3 cm according to MRI and mammo, the PET scan seem to show even smaller).  The SNB showed 1/4 nodes involved, but the neo chemo was the treatment plan before those results were even available.  Any others here going that route?  Deal is done now but I was just wondering. As I said, first chemo was yesterday.  A/C x 4 and then I there will be 4 more but I am not sure of the cocktail.  Nuelasta shot today and I am just waiting for that horror to kick in.  A lot of people on my chemo board have bone pain with it.  Main SE right now are just fatigue, total and complete disinterest in food, mild nausea but more of a "lump in the throat" feeling that makes me feel like I will be sick if I try to eat.  Currently working on a Boost protein drink and trying to get it all down. Well, that's about it for now... Dx 2/17/2012, IDC, 3cm, Stage IIB, Grade 3, 1/4 nodes, ER+/PR+, HER2+ Surgery 2/27/2012 Lymph node removal: Right, Sentinel Chemotherapy 3/19/2012 AC Targeted Therapy 6/11/2012 Herceptin (trastuzumab) Chemotherapy 6/11/2012 Taxotere (docetaxel) Surgery 10/1/2012 Mastectomy: Right; Prophylactic mastectomy: Left; Reconstruction (left): Tissue expander placement; Reconstruction (right): Tissue expander placement Radiation Therapy 11/13/2012 Breast, Lymph nodes Hormonal Therapy 11/18/2012 Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Stage IIb/Neoadjuvant Chemo kltb04 vballmom

Posts.Content: Mar 15, 2012 07:40AM - edited Mar 15, 2012 07:42AM by kltb04 That is what has gotten to me too - the waiting.  I am fortunate that I was able to stop working at my little part time job that was just "extra" so I don't have to deal with work.  But I guess I thought that I would be doing all these tests in a matter of a couple days and then starting treatment.  It has still gone pretty quickly.( 2/17 dx, 2/22 meet w/BS, 2/27 SNB, 3/1 meet w/MO, 3/7 PET, 3/9 CT/MUGA/Port, 3/14 follow up surgery to clean out after SNB) but I just had no idea all these tests/scans/etc were involved before you even got started.  Not to mention the u/s I have for my gallbladder today simply because it showed up on the PET scan - hello, I have cancer, we can deal with my gallbladder later??? I don't know what I did before all this. It literally is my life now.
Posts.Title: worried about everything anndh christina0001

Posts.Content: May 15, 2012 12:22AM kltb04 wrote: Sparksybrat - I don't think we have ever talked but I just wanted to let you know someone else was thinking of you...I was just rereading some emails I had sent to friends during my diagnosis time and it was hard even reading them.  Hang in there, etc...I know you have probably heard all the platitudes :) so I will leave it at that.
Posts.Title: Biopsy today, thank u everyone Sparkysbrat Sparkysbrat

Posts.Content: May 28, 2012 08:53AM kltb04 wrote: So glad you asked someone to come with you. Are you doing A/C first? If so and like others have said you will probably be fine the first couple days. For me the worst days are usually the night of 3 through about 5. This round has been longer because I am in round 4/4. (nothing unmanageable just feeling bleh). My SE are made worse by the nuelasta shot the day after chemo though. Do you know if you'll be getting that? Regardless you may find you can drive yourself to and from the next few but it's always good to have someone with you the first time. My drs office lets someone stay with you if you want. They may have to sit in the floor if the chairs are full but they never ask anyone to leave.
Posts.Title: I am finding it hard to ask for help pamelahope NWArtLady

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2012 10:45AM kltb04 wrote: Thanks for the continued responses - lele, I took Claritin so same idea...I don't know if it helped but it couldn't have hurt and I will continue to take it during the time of the shot. So much better this week...my WBC was still low (3.6, not bottomed out but still below normal) so I have been lying low this week.  Appetite is back with a vengeance so no worries there.  Had some constipation issues so I started on a stool softener.  But feeling better lets me know that this is definitely doable!
Posts.Title: Stage IIb/Neoadjuvant Chemo kltb04 vballmom

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2012 02:22PM kltb04 wrote: Lynda - I cannot imagine that I will have anything other than BMX...I know that is a hot topic on these boards but it is the only choice that I am comfortable with. My girls seem to be fine - we told the oldest the basics right after I got my biopsy results - she was very "suspicious" as I usually was the one taking them to and from school, home all the time and she overheard whispered conversations.  We told her breast cancer, very treatable, etc...with my younger one, we just told her a "boobie problem" for the first few weeks.  After I got my wig and we told her I would lose my hair from the medicine, we went ahead and used "the C word" but again, tried to keep it positive.  So I don't know if they are just putting on an act or if they are really ok, but they seem to be hanging in for now.
Posts.Title: Stage IIb/Neoadjuvant Chemo kltb04 vballmom

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 09:11PM kltb04 wrote: hillck - I have never in my life suffered from a lack of appetite so this is a new one.  Just sent DH to the store for hummus, cheese dip, almonds, and crackers.  These are the only things in the world I could think that I could eat tonight.  LOL. Momine - that is what my surgeon indicated - she said she prefers to see it shrink, see what works, etc.. she is young and seems to be "with it" as far as the latest and greatest treatments, presents at conferences etc... I am going to start trying to walk tomorrow at least a little bit.
Posts.Title: Stage IIb/Neoadjuvant Chemo kltb04 vballmom

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 10:46PM kltb04 wrote: Thanks. They are brothers - both fat and spoiled. We had a third that was younger and really funny but we just had to "rehome" her this week. We had her from a tiny kitten and about a year ago she decided she hated one of the boys. Beat him up and freaked out on him. Poor cat has spent the last 6 months in oldest DD's room hiding. My dx was the straw that broke the camels back. She was really wild and spastic and was always running all over us to the point I was scared I would be scratched to bits when she went on a tear So we gave her to someone who works at the same company DH works at. So now we are down to two and that's how it will stay!
Posts.Title: Stage IIb/Neoadjuvant Chemo kltb04 vballmom

Posts.Content: Mar 30, 2012 12:17PM kltb04 wrote: Thanks hillck. Lynda - please do - it helps to go through this with people with similar pathologies.  Looks like we are very similar except for the HER2 status.  I am going to just post on here about how things are going and hope others do the same.  Also, when you start your chemo, hop on a board for that month (April or whatever) and post there too - even if people are going through it at a different time/stage or even different drugs, it helps to see what their SE are, how they are coping etc...

It makes your life so much easier as far as blood draws and infusions. I have my second chemo Monday. Started losing/shedding the hair last weekend so I cut it short and then buzzed it to a three with DH clippers. Haven't given it a second thought. Don't love the look obviously but it hasnt bothered me much.

Posts.Content: Apr 23, 2012 07:06PM kltb04 wrote: If anyone reads this and wants to PM me about neo chemo or anything, feel free.  I am going to remove it from my favorites as I mostly post on a chemo board here...but always like to hear from people going through similiar situations...
Posts.Title: Stage IIb/Neoadjuvant Chemo kltb04 vballmom

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2012 12:58PM kltb04 wrote: Thanks all for the input/support - I really love the chemo board I am on but 95% of them have already had their surgeries so it helps to hear from others who have been through the same. Not incapacitated with the chemo but definitely down and out...still some mild nausea (even with the Zofran)...tomorrow is my last day of the antibiotics that I have to take on an empty stomach and feel that might help some.  (I developed an infection between the time of my SNB and my port insertion surgery that was cultured in my blood - still don't know where it came from but I have to be on antibiotics for 2 weeks to ensure it is gone).  I know I am not supposed to lose weight on chemo but I have lost about 10 lbs.  I have plenty to lose (I could lose another 50 and still not be at my ideal weight) but I know it isn't the time to be losing!    The second day/night after the shot was the worst - it wasn't the long bone pain I had been warned about, it was just allover pain...I told DH it felt like my skin hurt!   Anyway, I have labs tomorrow to check my counts - which involves an hour long drive/trip to the MO but I guess at least it will give me something to do!
Posts.Title: Stage IIb/Neoadjuvant Chemo kltb04 vballmom
